text: Now, I've heard there was a secret chord
That David played, and it pleased the Lord
But you don't really care for music, do you?
It goes like this, the fourth, the fifth
The minor fall, the major lift
Your faith was strong but you needed proof
You saw her bathing on the roof
Her beauty and the moonlight overthrew ya
She tied you to a kitchen chair
She broke your throne, and she cut your hair
And from your lips she drew the hallelujah
You say I took the name in vain
I don't even know the name
But if I did, well really, what's it to you?
There's a blaze of light in every word
It doesn't matter which you heard
The holy or the broken hallelujah
I did my best, it wasn't much
I couldn't feel, so I tried to touch
I've told the truth, I didn't come to fool you
And even though it all went wrong
I'll stand before the lord of song
With nothing on my tongue but hallelujah

content.text: Seduced by her beauty the male figure is bound into her domestic arrangements. There are not many references to the kitchen in LC's work, but it seems to mean something like the economy, where the arrangements are made that determine 'who will serve and who will eat'.
The old patriarchal spiritual hierarchy is destroyed, as is the source of the prophet's power (recall the secret to Samson's strength is his hair).
